key_points: The MFA (Museum of Fine Arts) is featuring artist posters as part of Carrie Mae Weems’s “RESIST COVID/ TAKE 6” project to highlight COVID-19's disproportionate impact on minority communities.
One poster displays a black-and-white photo of a Black man, aiming to raise awareness about racial inequity and the pandemic's toll.
RESIST posters, fliers, and digital banners are displayed across various public spaces in Boston and other major cities.
The campaign is a global movement, according to Edward Saywell, chair of the MFA's Prints and Drawings department.
Weems approached the MFA with the campaign in December, after starting work on it during the early lockdowns.
The campaign includes multiple messages, emphasizing systemic racism, violence, the importance of vaccination, and gratitude towards frontline workers.
Kristen Gresh, MFA's senior photography curator, emphasized the poster's dual message on systemic violence and COVID-19's disproportionate effects.
Another poster promotes vaccination as the best defense against the virus.
The project promotes collaboration and public art's role in community connection and dialogue.
It also aligns with the MFA's commitment to public art forms accessible from the street.
spokespersons: Edward Saywell (Chair, Prints and Drawings Department, MFA)
